title: NATO-3M adapter for gas masks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this adapter to let me use 3M respirator filters on my Swedish army forces M90 gas mask, also known as "Forsheda F2". But this adapter will "probably" fit any NATO threaded gas mask and will allow you to use "off the shelf" 3M filters.

Feel free to post you prints!

Printer:

Geeetech G2s Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

~0.2mm

Infill:

High

Finishing touches:

Round of the lower edge of the NATO threads, if needed.

Design aspects:

This adapter is my original drawing, the design is made to be strong and extra printer friendly with no bridges or steep slopes. It is designed with just the right amount of clearance and should work fine unmodified with most printers.

CAD files:

I also posted the Rhino .3dm file which allows you use the adapter threads on any other project, like for example filtering the air from your 3D printer.

comments.text:
Cool
When I was in we had the M40 gas masks, pretty cool to make an adapter to use standard 3M particulate/vapor filters...not NBC capable...but still cool as heck to use one for painting or other hazardous materials

author: Nleinad

description.text: This is a cookie cutter made using Cookie Caster's live trace option and the unBound logo.

12/8/2017: After all the interest this quad generates over the years.. You'd think SOMEBODY would at least tip a buck for it! The original quad is long gone! It fell to its final demise some years ago into Chevy Dealership. Luckily it crashed between two cars and nobody was hit. But it crashed so hard that it scattered itself like a grenade. The crash was attributed to flying over too strong of a WiFi signal. One second everything was fine, the next we were a uncontrolled falling object.
10/1/2014 : What you are looking at is the original prototype. This started as a printing exercise about a year ago. It was a mixture of MikeyB's Crossfire and some tweaked bits to fit the hardware I had.
This actual quad still exists. (At least most of the hardware does.) Its probably been wiped out, redesigned and reprinted about 20 times. Its still green & white, but now it has a completely different shape with an FPV system installed.
Look here for the current version : http://www.leftcoast.biz/iWeb/Left_Coast/Quadcopters.html Why build a quad? Here's a video teaser we made with them : http://vimeo.com/108092499

The orignial source for most of the parts are in the crossfire II file. Except the antenna mount and that is in.. The Antenna mount file. Everything was designed in Sketchup. Mostly 'cause I could get it for free and the "Crossfire" came that way.
First I printed the "Crossfire". And that was cool Thank you VERY MUCH MikeyB!
Then there was the madness of sourcing parts. How do people choose? Really, its a nightmare. There are so many motors, controllers, motor drivers and props.. They tell you the info. is all on the web. It is, but they don't mention that much is out of date. And, where on the web, might I ask? Its not like its all gathered in one spot. One website did point to a calculator..
http://www.ecalc.ch
With this you can see if your combo. should work. When it doesn't, you're back to the hobby shop pages looking for different combinations. Then, when you finally find a setup you like.. You may find they don't ship those bits to the US.
Anyway I finally found a set of parts that "should" work and I could buy online.
Here's the part list to build this thing. I Bought everything at HobbyKing. I'm guessing they're an importing house from Hong Kong. Turns out their warehouse is not far from me so I got my parts lickety-split. And their online help was VERY handy at the end.
http://www.hobbyking.com
â¢ (Motor controller) Q Brain 4 x 20A Brushless Quadcopter ESC 2-4S 3A SBEC PRODUCT ID: 9020000001
â¢ (Prop Green RH) Slow Fly Electric Prop 1045R SF (4 pc - Green Right Hand Rotation) - PRODUCT ID: 9329000029
â¢ (Prop Black RH) Slow Fly Electric Prop 1045R SF RH Rotation (4 pc) - PRODUCT ID: 9329000027
â¢ (Prop Green LH)) Slow Fly Electric Prop 1045 SF (4 pc - Green) - PRODUCT ID: 9329000028
â¢ (Prop Black LH) Slow Fly Electric Prop 1045SF (4 pc) - PRODUCT ID: 9329000026
â¢ (Brain box with sensors) MultiWii PRO Flight Controller w/MTK GPS Module - PRODUCT ID: 387000003
â¢ (Batery) Turnigy nano-tech 5000mah 3S 45~90C Lipo Pack - PRODUCT ID: N5000.3S.45
â¢ (Low voltage alarm for LiPo battery) On-Board Lipoly Low Voltage Alarm 2s~3s - PRODUCT ID: 067000002
â¢ (The motors) D2830-11 1000kv Brushless Motor - PRODUCT ID: D2830-111000
Well, my parts didn't really fit the "Crossfire". The motors did. Yay! But nothing else.. So thats when I started changing things around.
Then... Then there was the endless configuration and programming the controllers etc. Oh my lord!
1) If you bought a new radio, (I did) you have to "bind" the transmitter to the receiver. Not tough, but needs doing.
2) Now with the radio working.. You have to initialize the motor controller to your radio. The controller has step by step on this. (Only thing that had a manual.) P.S. When they say with props removed? THEY MEAN IT. These things are lethal!
3) - The brain box is really an Arduino Mega. To load your firmware your going to need to get the Arduino programming stuff. Then you will have to customize the config.h file to suit your machine & radio setup. What fun!
The code for the MultiWii comes with a java control panel that will show you what's going on inside your machine's head. This is a life saver!
NOTE : If your running Mac OSX 8+ Moutan lion. You will have to get the silicon labs USB driver. Cause Moutan Lion has a bug so it can't see all this stuff.
http://www.silabs.com/products/mcu/pages/usbtouartbridgevcpdrivers.aspx
You will find the pinouts and configuration info. on the page where you ordered the controller. Not all, but some.
Printing, I printed the arms and the body parts standard with the fill upped to 25%. The other bits just standard.
So here it is. It does fly. Its hard to keep it on the ground. I need to learn how to fly it.
Have fun!

description.text:
An 8th grade science / engineering project about buoyancy. The students design a boat to hold as many pennies as possible before sinking or capsizing. After testing their boats they try to redesign it to improve the performance.

The models here are the student's second designs. A lab report and student examples are also included.
CCSS

An 8th grade science / engineering project about buoyancy.  The students design a boat to hold as many pennies as possible before sinking or capsizing. After testing their boats they try to redesign it to improve the performance.
The models here are the student's second designs. A lab report and student examples are also included.

!. Before starting our unit on buoyancy, density, and Archimedes Principle the students were challenged to design a vessel that could hold the most pennies in water before sinking or capsizing
  • Student models were resized to use 25 g of plastic to make the contest fair (not counting supports, if needed).
  • Boats were printed and tested after we completed our lessons on buoyancy, density and Archimedes Principle.
  • Students used what they learned to design a second boat.
  • Second generation boats were tested.
Water, containers, pennies

description.text:

These are the air plants we used: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00DIGVDV8/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

This is a Calculus manipulative to allow students to learn integral methods hands-on (specifically finding the volume by cylindrical shells).

print_settings.Notes:: The design dimensions are 116mmx68mmx170mm. Infill must be 100% rectilinear to avoid the possibility of leaks. Try printing 18.stl and compare to comparison.jpg to ensure your printer is correctly configured, Also check your retraction settings because printing the perc holes is a challenge without it . The print requires about 270gms of filament. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND  PRINTING THE PERCOLATOR SLOW.

title: straight tube dual bubbly/honeycomb-like bubbler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Good Day, today I bring a straight tube bubbly/honeycomb-like perc water pipe . I recommend using slic3r for gcode (this design has many small holes and will affect stl loading time in slic3r, please be patient). I have personally checked that all layers are correct and no random gaps will occur during the print. I decided not to attach a base because It doesn't have overhangs. Good Luck. For more info take a look at Good Day.txt

NEVER LIGHT PLASTIC ON FIRE, THE POISONUS FUMES ARE DEADLY, use a glass bowl or attachment. I do not condone under age smoking.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200-300 microns (.2mm-.3mm)

Infill:

100% rectilinear (is a must)

Notes:

The design dimensions are 116mmx68mmx170mm. Infill must be 100% rectilinear to avoid the possibility of leaks. Try printing 18.stl and compare to comparison.jpg to ensure your printer is correctly configured, Also check your retraction settings because printing the perc holes is a challenge without it . The print requires about 270gms of filament. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND PRINTING THE PERCOLATOR SLOW.

author: 3ndo

description.text:
This is a remix from (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:345958).

It prints great in PLA and will fit the 1.63 inch display. I could have spent more time and cleaned up the bottom but was just looking for something quick and simple. I'm more interested in creating a TPU case for the watch so please modify and make this PLA version better. I did add a cut out hole for the microphone on the watch.

11/8/2016. Added V3 which has a thinner top (over the watch face) and also slightly moved the mic hole. I printed v3 this in white PETG (245 nozzle 90 bed) and it came out great.

11/14/2016. I created a TPU case. Check it out. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1891779

After adding insulation and glass to my print bed I found I had taken at least a half inch of my z axis out of commission! These extenders bump the threaded rods about a inch up, extending the axis back to normal. I think this may only work if your print bed is higher than the usual. You will have to drill out the holes to your desired size.
I used m3 bolts, but the holes will have to be drilled, so anything you have laying around will work as long as you have the right bit.

Your_Text = Possibility Zone

My 3 year old is in love with a TV Show called the Octonauts. It's new here in the US and has been out in England for a little longer. She has to watch it every day and since it started airing she has constantly being running around the house pretending to be one of the Characters. So after not being able to find any toys or anything else here in the US I promptly designed it myself.

Print the badge and one of the clips.
sand the parts if you feel the need to.
Paint the badge. The Octopus should be white and the background should be blue. the Ring around the outside should be white as well.
Superglue the clip onto the back of the badge. Give the badge to your kidlet and be their hero or at least be awesome in their eyes for a whole day.

comments.text: Thanks for the model. I printed two out and painted them up for my kids now they are running round saying "octo-Alert!".

title: Granville Gee Bee Z40 simplified cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Developed in the 1930s, this beauty was able to fly over 450 km/h (280 mph) powered by a 700 hp nine-cylinder, air-cooled, radial engine. So essentially the Z40 was a big fat engine with little wings. That makes it looks like a comic version of a plane and it was probably pretty tricky to fly.

This small-scale simplified realization pays tribute to the chubby look of the original. The build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6.5 mm beech plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. Glued together and nicely sanded it's a great toy for boys (of different age).
A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create smaller versions.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Spielsachen/Flugzeugmodelle for more designs.

Consider a small donation (1$) if you like this design. Any amount will help me keeping up with my work.

Keep in mind, that the stl-file is just for validating the construction and viewing in the browser.

author: ZenziWerken

print_settings.Notes:: For speed of prototyping, I printed the prototypes at .2mm.

description.text:
An angel tea light, for my angel of course! Also planning on using these for stocking stuffers at Christmas.

Two pieces to print, and a tea light to purchase (I used the "flickering" effect tea light).

Video of prototype here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8kCd0VV2uk0.

Designed using Sketchup Make 2016, sliced with Cura, and printed in PLA on an Ultimaker 2 Extended.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For speed of prototyping, I printed the prototypes at .2mm.

Parts I Purchased:

1) Flickering candle effect tea light (box stores, craft stores, amazon).

Printing:

Print 1 each of the two parts.

Assembly:

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. both parts as necessary for tight fit . Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.

1) After clean up, press "Angel Tea Light Small.stl" into "Angel Tea Light Small Base.stl".

2) Test fit your tea lamp in "Angel Tea Light Small Base.stl". The base opening for the tea lamp is 40mm in diameter which was chosen after a few different brands of tea lights were tried. Some brands fits tight, others fit loose. If your tea lamp is loose, wrap tape around the circumference of the tea lamp base until a tight fit is attained.

Hope you like it!

title: PlateR
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A quick openScad file I threw together to try and make a customised number plate

Its just for a bit of fun, and my SCAD code isnt that good (I'm like 3 years rusty... dont expect polished code) But have a play :)

While this thing scales for different numbers of letters (in the main plate, not the top and bottom text), the ideal length is 6-7 characters (spaces count), and the further away from this you go the more likely there is to be some glitches... that said, I did test it with a 26 letter combo, and it looked ok

So have fun :) Please let me know what you think

Post Printing

While this project is ideal for dual colour (single or dual extruder), if like me you only have 1 role of filament to hand, Just print it in one colour, and then use a permanent marker to colour the letters and edging... that's what I did.

Test tube hyperboloid vase

This is holder to arrange test tubes in a hyperboloid and hold flowers in a pretty pattern.
There are four versions: for 10 or 12 tubes and for 16mm and for 19mm tubes.

The test tubes need to be held snug, you might have to scale the model up or down 1-2% depending on the specific tubes and filament properties.

Have you ever needed to pour two things and mix them too? Now you can with this two chambered mixing funnel. By the time the two liquids come out the tip they should be nice and mixed.

Print the funnel with the tip up and the two large chambers down.

title: Hyundai armrest replacement clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The armrest clip on my 2013 Hyundai broke, so I decide to print a replacement for it, this clip is printed with ABS and only 7% infill, creating a very flexible part on the spring and body, the lock head is designed with thick walls to make it strong even with low infill.

To install the clip, just use the guide on the back of the model to centered it and push it down until it locks in place.

Hopefully this part is useful to someone; I’m including the original sketchup file in case someone need to customized this model.

Update 11/03/2016:
If you are having problems with the clip not holding tight the armrest, I have added the v2 model that will fix this issue.

title: Shutter Cable Release Adapter Tapered Threads (S.C.R.A.T.T.)

description.text: Imagine, for a moment, that you have built a camera. Further, imagine that you desire to use a remote cable release to trigger the shutter. After excitedly purchasing your cable release, you notice that the threads are a strange and obscure tapered arrangement, a configuration not to be found on the shelves of your favorite hardware store. Using your new remote trigger cable is going to require adapting something completely ill-suited to the purpose (a standard M3 nut, for instance, only engages the largest threads). A tapered thread tap, perhaps? Ha ha ha! Just try to find what you need on the Interwebs. Go ahead. I'll wait. It's not out there, but, hopefully, this bit of data can solve your problem. This is intended to be a negative space to receive the cable release conical threads. Incorporated into another three dimensional structure, you can add a provision for a remote shutter to any thing conceivable. This probably cannot be effectively 3D printed on a consumer-grade FDM machine (it's tiny!), but services like Shapeways can print at greater resolution/accuracy. Time will tell. I'll let you know. The B&W photo is a quad-sized test print that meshes perfectly. I now have a properly-sized SLS-printed product from Shapeways for your own homemade camera adventures - https://www.shapeways.com/model/1512877/shutter-cable-release-adapters-tapered-threads.html. Very affordable in White, Strong Nylon. See photos. Additionally, I have included some double-sized parts (labeled accordingly). The original is so small as to have rendering issues at true size. Hopefully shrinking a larger object by 50% will preserve detail. Use your favorite CAD editor to customize and scale what you need. For some reason, Thingiverse is not rendering these parts, but they appear to be real STLs, available for download. Let me know if you have problems with these files.

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

The precise spec for the "Shutter cable release tip and socket" are contained in an arcane publication from the International Standards Organization, ISO 6053:1979. I haven't seen this document, and my working spec come from a decade-old, crowd-sourced, and empirically-derived exchange of information on photo.net.
http://photo.net/bboard/q-and-a-fetch-msg?msg_id=003RAb "Thread pitch is 0.5mm. Thread length is 2.5mm. Overall taper angle is 30 degrees, or 15 degrees per side. Maximum thread diameter is 3.4mm..." NEWS UPDATE: I have since found an American Standards Assn document that disproves the one assumption I made: The thread profile is NOT perpendicular to the 15ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ° angle of the taper, but perpendicular to the central axis of the threads. See for yourself:
http://s274.photobucket.com/user/Glennza/media/CableReleaseLarge.jpg.html I fixed these discrepancies in a newer OpenSCAD file, called tapered_thread_V2.scad. Apologies if you downloaded the original file with the geometrical error. I modified the OpenSCAD scripting from "Metric Screw Thread Library", thing:31363, by marcaxi. There is a certain elegance in his code, the mechanism of which eluded me for a while. Special thanks to aubenc also, for thoughtful consideration of this small (literally) project. I don't expect that you need to monkey with parameters much to generate usable threads, but feel free to adapt to other tapering spiral applications. If I can help you use these files in your camera, I am at your disposal. Finally, these files are freely available for download, distribution with attribution, but not for commercial purposes. I might be talking to you, China.

title: Old World Trade Center Complex After Destruction

description.text:
This 3D printed model features the old World Trade Center Complex (12 days after destruction based on the LIDAR point cloud data taken by the USGS AVIRIS imaging system). All 7 buildings were destroyed on September 11th 2001. WTC 1 & 2 = 110 stories, WTC 3 = 22 stories, WTC 4 = 9 stories, WTC 5 = 9, WTC 6 = 8 stories & WTC 7 = 47 stories. All 4 towers were almost completely destroyed. Please let this aid your research into the destruction of the World Trade Center complex.

The pictured model was printed on a ProJet 1500 3D printer. Cost was $.30/g, so this one ended up costing $52. It measures 5"(W)X5(L)"X2.5"(H). The build plate brings the height total to 3.2".

Where Did The Towers Go?

I AM NOT THE CREATOR, just trying to share.

Use this manipulative to build an intuitive understanding of how the "b" coefficient of a quadratic function affects the graphed parabola. Here's a quick overview video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PmrzcR4H6xw Given a quadratic equation of the form: y = ax^2 + bx + c The "a" coefficient stretches the parabola vertically. The "c" coefficient moves the parabola up and down. These are easy to understand. But the "b" coefficient is a little more tricky. Use this manipulative to get a feel for how it works. For teachers I've included the following: 1) Non-verbal instructions for assembling (pdf file). I like giving students opportunities to practice following visual instructions. 2) Exploration Guide (pdf file). Good questions for project-based learners to explore parabolas using this manipulative. 3) A game-based virtual manipulative for students to interact with online: http://sso.stmath.com/demo/parabola/ParabolaManipulative.html Here are the Common Core standards connected to this manipulative: F_IF.7, G_GPE_3.1 (California addition), G_GPE.1 and G_GPE.2. The source files in SketchUp are also provided in a zip archive.

Print out all the parts and then follow the visual instructions in the Visual_Instructions.pdf file.  
Here are the colored filaments I used for the different parts:  
WHITE: Parabola Backbone.stl, Parabola Frame.stl, Parabola Slope Knob.stl  
BLACK: Parabola Slope Bar.stl, Parabola Slope Pin.stl  
BLUE: Parabola Rods.stl

An experimental 3D printable linear bearing that uses circular slides to (in theory) reduce surface area and friction. This type of bearing (in theory) should show equal performance of 3D printed linear fin bearings while lasting longer and being able to bear more weight. Use the customizer to match your own size bearing.

The photos show a standard size LM8UU bearing using four sliders. I have not tested the effects of the number and radius of the sliders, it would be awesome if someone could test them and let me know the results.

comments.text: Conceptually, I see where you are coming from but I sense it will produce drag especially as material waste builds up... I could be wrong in my thinking but it seems to be the case in my test run on my Chinese knock off printer.
comments.author: Pyr3x

comments.text:
Did you try it ?
The contact "surface" against the round smooth rod will in fact be a line that will wear out quickly to become more like the standard contact area found in regular "plastic" bearings, but you will get excessive play. Same if it is a tight fit, the smooth rod will imprint itself, then wear out but a least the play will be less if any. So unless you demonstrate otherwise, better use the proven approach.

This is an RC controller I designed to go with my electric skateboard. Was previously using a RC car controller but it was excessively bulky and ate a lot of batteries. Designed this one around using an arduino nano and rf module on the transmitter and receiver sides and just wrote some code to read a potentiometer in the transmitter here and sends it along to another one that then uses the servo library to send a signal to the ESC that controls the motor.

1_1 Made trigger a bit longer though it wasn't trouble in use the trigger could slip in the main controller area before, also spread out are where the spring mounts between spring and main controller body. Increased size of cover since it was falling into the bottom section when screwed on. Increased height of main controller body to account for potentiometer height so it doesn't rub on the lid, also increased USB and switch hole sizes to make inserting components easier.

Update 1
Added an image of the wiring, considering getting some PCBs printed to simplify connecting the components since the wiring did end up being a bit of a rats nest. Would be around $10-$15 a piece to get a few made. Uploaded images of the built controller as well. The wiring for the receiver is the same with the exception that the analog (A1) is used on the transmitter to read the position of the potentiometer whereas on the receiver the digital pin D5 (PWM) is used to send the microSecond pulses for controlling the ESC.

If using the code below first turn on the transmitter then sweep the trigger to max and min positions this will calibrate the values used to map the max/minimum it sends to the receiver. Power on the receiver after the calibration is done otherwise you will have a run away vehicle.

Update 2
Didn't note it in the wiring diagram or text before here but good to put an electrolytic capacitor between ground and vin on the arduino (around 100uF ~16V one is working well for me) This was needed on the receiver side or else it seems the VESC's BEC that was giving me the 5V to run the arduino would occasionally dip when the motor was drawing a lot of power and the dip was enough for some part of the arduino to brown out. Since adding the capacitor between ground and Vin (make sure polarity is correct) the LEDs shine bright and it hasn't browned out again yet (biggest problem I had since was loose connections between receiver and ESC but soldered those on and has been a solid connection for the last few days).

On a more positive note the controller lasts forever on a charge. In wanting to verify the charger was working after installing the guts in a new print and took a good hour before the voltage had even dipped enough for the charger to not consider it 100% full (I checked with a voltmeter as well and was sitting around 4.14V), so super happy with the efficiency of the whole thing even without any tuning in that regard.

Update 3
https://github.com/shusain/eskatecontroller Posting further updates for the Arduino code and Eagle files for making PCBs to connect the Arduino (pro mini 3.3V) to the nordic RF modules. Found using Arduino Nano I was getting drop outs on the receiver side occasionally (possibly due to fluctuations in em interference on the 5V supply, but seems stable so far with 3.3V). The PCB design is exported as pcb.png in the eagle folder for a single sided DIY at home PCB.

Update 4
Adding a box used for the receiver on the board, also updated the PNG in the linked github repo for at PCB making to work for both the controller and receiver and use a servo style JST plug where the power is in the center and ground is on the edge to avoid accidental reversing the polarity (not that I did that).

Update 5
Working on a new version of this using parametric CAD software to make it easier to tweak the design and refine it. Ordered PCBs from pcbway, was $28 for 10 boards delivered (slight discount for first order) they were of acceptable quality to me and have worked well for the last 6 months or so.

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/50e9e32d777391df91fbe5a9/w/19598faab2182f3b574dcfaf/e/52a747c0c2e141ee735a22b8

Update 6
Added new images and STL files for the onshape based one with the new custom PCBs. 4 new STL files for the controller (all start with RC Controller - )

Code

RC Controller Code

#include <SPI.h>
#include "nRF24L01.h"
#include "RF24.h"
int msg[1];
RF24 radio(9,10);
const uint64_t pipe = 0xE8E8F0F0E1LL;
int SW1 = 7;

int sensorPin = A1;    // select the input pin for the potentiometer
int sensorValue = 0;  // variable to store the value coming from the sensor

//These values are used to keep track of bounds of the analog input
//the values are translated into a range of 1-255 to transmit to the
//receiver, on that side it will map the value to 1500-2000 micro seconds
//for the ESC
int max = -10000; //Calibrate by moving the joystick to it's max and minimum values
int min = 10000;

void setup() {
  radio.begin();
  radio.openWritingPipe(pipe);
  Serial.begin(9600);
}

void loop() {
  // read the value from the sensor:
  sensorValue = analogRead(sensorPin);

  if(sensorValue>max)
    max = sensorValue;
  if(sensorValue<min)
    min = sensorValue;

  int mappedValue = map(sensorValue, min,max,1,255);

  if(mappedValue<1)
    mappedValue = 1;
  if(mappedValue>255)
    mappedValue = 255;

  Serial.println(mappedValue);

  msg[0] = mappedValue;
  radio.write(msg, 1);
}

RC receiver code

#include <SPI.h>
#include <elapsedMillis.h>
#include "nRF24L01.h"
#include "RF24.h"
#include "Servo.h"

int msg[1];
RF24 radio(9,10);
const uint64_t pipe = 0xE8E8F0F0E1LL;
int LED1 = 13;
Servo myServo;
elapsedMillis timeElapsed;

void setup(void){
  Serial.begin(9600);

  radio.begin();
  radio.openReadingPipe(1,pipe);
  radio.startListening();
  pinMode(LED1, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(5, OUTPUT);

  myServo.attach(5);
  myServo.writeMicroseconds(1500);
}
void loop(void){  
  if (radio.available()){
    bool done = false;
    while (!done){
      done = radio.read(msg, 1);
      if (msg[0] ==0){
        //Serial.println("Bad signal received");
        delay(10);
        digitalWrite(LED1, HIGH);
      } else {
        //Translates value sent over wifi to microseconds in range for ESC
        int msgInMicroSeconds = map(msg[0],1,255,1500,2000);
        Serial.println(msgInMicroSeconds);
        myServo.writeMicroseconds(msgInMicroSeconds);
        timeElapsed = 0;
        digitalWrite(LED1, LOW);
      }
      delay(10);
    }
  }
  else{
    delay(10);
  }
  // If no message was received and a second has passed put the ESC in neutral
  // safety feature in case we lose radio communication for some reason
  if(timeElapsed > 1000){
    myServo.writeMicroseconds(1750);
  }
}

comments.text: Yeah I haven't really noticed a lot of drift and have been using the board and controller for the last 5 months going through the winter and now in the summer without adjusting the hard coded values in the controller/transmitter code for mapping the values.  I just updated the png in the eagle folder for making a PCB if you want to do that as well, makes for a much more solid connection in the end rather than a bundle of wires and end up with a little sandwich of PCBs instead.  Only down side with the new design is I was focused on the receiver side mostly so forgot that the potentiometer in the controller side needs a VCC line but you can just tap that off the top of the arduino with a wire really so don't think it's a huge deal, maybe will correct it tomorrow if I still have motivation left :).

comments.text: So while I am waiting for my parts to arrive I was wondering if this remote is 'city-proof' i.e. does it still function in a very crowded 2.4 ghz band. In dutch cities it is quite common to receive 25-50 different wifi connections per street I don't know how this is regulated in the USA but here it is one big mess.
comments.author: jobbzz

comments.text: Yeah same wifi mess here in general.  I live on the edge of Chicago so pretty densely populated neighborhood and don't have any problems with it.  Not sure the exact frequencies these operate at you'd need to check the RF library docs or whitepaper/datasheet for the Nordic RF module since all the wifi devices work on some channel range around the 2.4GHz frequency.  So far as I've seen there aren't any major problems with wifi interference though... the chips do some sort of packet verification and retransmission automatically and don't connect to standard wifi access points so not sure if they use the typical range of channels (I did read up on it in the docs and you can adjust this value but I forget the details off hand).  You can also adjust the power level on the transmitter (in the setup Arduino code), think you want the lowest possible so long as the signal doesn't drop, even on low power though at such a short distance it doesn't have much trouble.  That said having your body between the transmitter and receiver does block the signal pretty well so having it at medium or higher is a bit safer I think since the signal can also bounce off the ground or other objects and hit the receiver even if your body is in the way.
comments.author: jobbzz

comments.text: Nice to hear! Yeah in Europe they are also selling 5.8ghz routers nowadays but since the wave lenght is shorter on this frequency it doesn't penetrate through objects that easliy but to compensate that they put more energy in it. Also it is said that the 5.8ghz band should be faster due to the shorter wavelengths although I don't think the difference in speed is really noticeable. (At least not for my crappy internet connection) anyway this comment becomes a bit off topic !

comments.text: Just pushed a change to the code to only use values between 1 and 254 because both 0 and 255 can come back from the nrf module if there is a bad signal or loose connection (found out when my MOSI solder point gave out and the board decided to go full throttle, which was a terrifying learning experience).  Be sure to test disconnecting every wire you can while the parts are still all laid out before you mount things to be sure it does "the right thing" in any given scenario to keep this a safe project, also make sure you update the code if you pulled it already (change was basically to go from 1-255 to 1-254 for the data transmitted so as to avoid those edges of 0 and 255 that the radio will send back if things aren't working properly, would maybe be good to adjust this in the RF24 available function but needed at least a temporary fix).

comments.text: I actually used the same arduino mini and nrf setup on the receiver side.  I'm aware the VESC can talk with the nrf module directly... now at least. When I started this wasn't aware of that though so I basically made this as a transmitter/receiver pair with an arduino pro mini and nrf module on both sides.  The one on the transmitter side reads the potentiometer and sends 1 byte over to the receiver, that maps the 1 byte into a value between 1500 and 2000 microseconds and then it uses the servo library to make a pwm signal that gets sent along a wire connected to the ESC on the longboard side.

comments.text: Hiya, sounds like a good deal. Regarding the batteries and power requirements, with LiPo for most cells you don't want them to get below 3.3 at minimum and when fully charged they're at 4.2V and when around the 50% range through most of their charge time their around 3.7V. In the controller I actually use I have a 5V arduino nano running off of one of those LiPo batteries without a voltage booster and the atmel chip still runs well enough on the controller side for everything to operate without an issue. I added a voltage regulator in the blue controller I had originally done since I was having the problems on the receiver side and was trying to eliminate possible problems but turns out it wasn't needed (especially if you use the 3.3v pro mini boards). Ultimately problem was just the 5V on the ESC side wasn't good/clean enough and apparently was dipping enough to cause the 5V nanos I had to black/brown out so using a 3.3V pro mini on the receiver/esc side is best bet I think.

comments.text: Yeah it's a combination of the controller and the programming of the ESC that will determine if it brakes or not.  With mine I'm using a VESC which has software configuration for adjusting the minimum and maximum microsecond values. Typcally 1500-2000 but mine are set something like 1700-2100, if you can't adjust this on the ESC you can just adjust the code on the receiver side to output lower microSecond values to the "servo" connection since that gets hooked up to the ESC.  In the typical case 1750 us(microseconds) wide high pulses indicate "neutral" and should be when your controller is in it's resting position, 2000us should be full acceleration when pulling the trigger and 1500us should be when fully pushing the brake (ideally, but all these values will vary a bit).  On the controller/transmitter side I have the code reading the analog value which it gets as a 0-1024 (10-bit) then map that value to 0-255 for the sake of sending a smaller 8 bit value over the radio frequency connection (the code I found only sent 1byte aka 8-bits), then on the receiver side I map the 0-255 into the micro second values the ESC expects so map value from 0-255 range to 1500-2000 to output as a microsecond pulse.  What the ESC does to control the motor with that 1500-2000 microsecond pulse is up to the ESC configuration but as described above 1750 typically neutral 1500 typically full brake 2000 typically full acceleration.

print_settings.Notes:: The bottom_pin should have a hexagonal fit so that top and top_pin cannot rotate against each other.

description.text:
Is it really necessary to mount filament spools vertically? Vertically obviously has the least chance for gravity to mess around and entangle layers on the spool. But let's see...

This is a thrust bearing for mounting a spool horizontally. It centers spools with a 19mm, 32mm or 52mm hole perfectly. Or any other if you don't mind that it moves a bit sideways..

To better fix spools on the center pin, some caps are available. Basically a cone centers the upper side of the spool. There is a short cap, for extreme narrow spools and a long cap for very wide spools. But in general the sponge cap should be able to cover most spool types.

The design was done with FreeCAD exercising the the sketch feature for most parts.
The bearing uses conical rollers and features a bottom opening, where a pin can be inserted, so that it will not fall apart as with other thrust bearings.

Printer:

Tinyboy Fabricator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed with Cura's concentric fill pattern on top and bottom. That yields nice and smooth tracks.

The 0.2 mm resolution should be changed to 0.1mm when printing top.stl and base.stl so that the slightly conical tracks are rendered in more steps.

The bottom_pin should have a hexagonal fit so that top and top_pin cannot rotate against each other.

Assembly

Put the rollers on the arms. They need to rotate freely. If not, watch out for loose filament like stringing or other defects.
The hexagon shaft of the bottom_pin should have a tight fit in the top and top_pin parts. If it is too loose apply some glue, if you cannot press it inwards, print another one scaled down to 99% or 98%. Theoretically there is 0.1mm clearance, that should give a snugly fit for most printers.

The caps are not really needed, they are a nice addition.

Pro-tip: apply some hot-glue to the bottom of the base. Then the mount stays in place and does not walk towards the printer, when it pulls in filament.

Math?

The cones for the tracks and the rollers need to match exactly, so that the roller wants to roll in the exact same circle where the arms would guide it. This does not need any math,
if you start with pointed cones (smaller diameter 0) and let tips of top, bottom, roller meet in the same point. Then enlarge the rollers by adding the same amount to both diameters.

No math needed!

Measurements:
Supported spool sizes include (Inner diameter / outer diameter / width)

  • 18.5mm / 128mm / 70mm Taulman 0.5kg
  • 31mm / 163mm / 84mm sainsmart 1kg
  • 53mm / 201mm / 65mm HERZ 1kg
  • 53mm / 204mm / 74mm 3dfuel 1kg
  • 57mm / 178mm / 93mm NuNus 1kg
Dummy round for 12 gauge shotgun. These should not be used for dry firing. Working on 12 gauge snap caps design

title: MP Select Mini X Gantry Support + Camera Mount [Reinforced and Realigned]

description.text:
This is a remix of the support pylon for FDM_Guru's excellent X Gantry Support System for the Monoprice Select Mini 3D printer.

It appears that there are now variations in different releases of this printer, as the dimensions for the original part differed substantially from my own printer ordered from MP on 2016-09-15. Issuing an M115 gcode on my printer returns the following information:

NAME: Malyan VER: 2.7 MODEL: M200 HW: HA02

The model is now exactly 120mm across which just fits the MP Select Mini 3D's build plate. This version has been extensively tested and aligns perfectly with the hole patterns on my printer.

This part is a reinforced bolt-over support pylon for a 6mm linear shaft. The panel thickness has been increased to reduce/remove flex, additional support has been provided by extending the part forward to one of the front screw mounts, screw holes have been recessed to fit the factory screw heads, and the pylon has been moved in order to fit my printer. The bearing holder has been extended to hold both bearings securely with two zip-ties each, and has an added lip around the front side of the gantry to constrain the part's placement and to provide additional rigidity.

I've created modified mounting pieces compatible with 3dkarma's Raspberry Pi Camera Mount. Both pieces provide zip-tie mounting to the bearing holder bracket, allowing you to attach accessories (such as the rPi camera) to the gantry which will move with the Z-axis. This is helpful for webcam monitoring of print progress as the camera will move vertically with the print as it builds up from the plate. The zip-tie mounting allows the placement of up to 8 arms on the gantry.

This build will require a pair of 6mm LM6LUU linear bearings and one 6mm x 300mm linear rail along with a pair of 8mm M3 screws + nuts to lock the linear rail into place on the support pylon (optional).

All credit goes to FDM_Guru for the original idea and for working through the dimension problems with me, janbbeck's idea to provide additional support, and 3dkarma for the camera mount.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50% triangular

Notes:

Printed on the MP select mini 3D using eSun PETG. All parts have been designed and oriented to print without support, just position them on your bed and hit print!

it's good for primary student

Last year, as a first year high school IT teacher, I assumed that all students were capable of reading a tape measure or ruler. Oh how I was wrong! Not only could my students not read a ruler, they also struggled with basic addition. This is where the BIGFOOT comes in handy!  
The BIGFOOT is 12" long so a student can visually see exactly how long a foot is as well as be able to use it as a ruler. If multiple BIGFOOTs are printed off, students can use them to measure objects and use them for basic estimation purposes.  
The BIGFOOT also has small holes which allow the INCH PEGS to be inserted into them. These inch pegs actually say the word "INCH" on the bottom of them so there is absolutely no confusion what the measurement is. Students can use these to measure small objects by lining them up one after another. Students can also use these inch pegs to visually see measurement fractions. For example, if there are 6 pegs inserted into the foot the student can visually see that half the foot is taken up which would be 6".  
I plan on posting a demonstration video within the next few days as well as posting a version of the BIGFOOT that can be printed in two parts for those of you who have small printers.
Print these out with at least 25% fill. I tried 10% fill and low quality which is why the print looks so rough in the pictures. Please let me know if there are any scaling issues.

title: Joseph Smith's Death Mask
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a scan of the Prophet Joseph Smith's death mask from the LDS Church History Museum in downtown Salt Lake City, UT. I still need to go in and clean up the back side so it has a flat back to print with as well as remove the bump on the chin from the stand the mask was sitting on.

Update 2 Oct 2017
I finally got around to smoothing out where the clips are and making a flat back to assist with printing. I'm not the most thrilled with the smooth job since it removes the texture that the rest of the mask scan has so I'm going to include several versions in addition to the original. This will give you options.

1) Original scan but now with a flat bottom
2) Fixed and the chin clip removed
3) Fixed and all clips removed

First I scanned the mask using 123Catch (http://www.123dapp.com/catch/Joseph-Smith-s-Death-Mask/5820290). Then I removed the extra parts from the scan using MeshMaker and repaired the file using NetFabb.

author: Zrako

description.text:
This is a spacer I designed for the Chinese (and similar) 100W LED modules commonly found on Amazon and eBay, and accounts for the space between the LED mounting surface, commonly a heatsink, and the lens holder, commonly the 44mm lens holders. I didn't feel like buying spacers or filling the gaps with washers and/or nuts, so I designed and printed my own.

As the shape and filename would suggest, this spacer has gone through a few revisions. The first was to accommodate and support the lens holder. Then notches were implemented for the solder tabs on the LED. Then finally, wire channels were added to tidy everything up.

Just as with any other project out there, use at your own risk. I have not fully tested this. I've had the LED (100W) on as long as it took for the heatsink to reach 110F and I shut it all down. This took all of about 15 seconds, so I cannot guarantee any reliability with prolonged use. This was designed for a studio light which will be used in flash photography, which shouldn't generate that much heat at all.

Use either M3 or 4-40 screws.

Rotate it X:180 degrees and no supports required.

This is my first upload. Enjoy!

author: kosei

description.text:
This Thing addresses a problem encountered when teaching "telling time" to children: the clock face is round but we talk about time as if it were linear. Elapsed time can be confusing, and then we get into digital clocks.  
This clock face consists of 12 identical 5-minute segments, hinged at the corners. Also included are the hubs to assemble the clock, pointers to note a time by clipping to the edge, and a set of hands and the hub for them.  
If an actual "face" is needed you can cut it out of foamcore; a regular dodecagon with ~183mm radius. The "hands hub" is a little longer, with a long part in the rear to poke into the center of the foamcore face.  
See the "Instructions" tab for info on how to use this.  
EDITED: because I forgot to upload the short hand, and also added a new pic showing the pointers (in red) printed and clipped to the edges.

This is intended for younger children, so it's designed "chunk style" and large enough for demonstrations.  
Print 12 5minute plates, 12 hourhubs, 1 long hand, 1 short hand, some pointers, and a hands hub. The 5minute plates must be printed with support because of the overhang.   
On a well tuned printer it all goes together without scraping or reaming. Assemble the 12 plates into a ring, add a foamcore face (as described above) if you want. (It's really not necessary.)  
You can teach time in the usual "long hand, short hand" way, but when it comes to elapsed time you can then unhook one pin and "lay time out in a line" so that the minutes can be counted.  
The hourhubs can be inserted from the front or back. If from the front, the large circular part can be used for writing numbers or holding stickers. (Use dry-erase markers and erase with pencil eraser.) Some kids find these numbers confusing (if the long hand is on the 12 first, then on the 4, 12-4=8, so 8 minutes have elapsed, right?) so you can also leave them blank or insert them from the rear instead.  
Digital time uses one labeled hour hub for the part "in front of the colon", then plates to add enough minutes to show the part "after the colon."

comments.text: I'm printing this now, hopefully it works good!! I used 1 spool out of the bag for a small print and it kept getting tangled. Hopefully this will fix that and i can swap it between the 4 spools I bought!
comments.author: sLpFhaWK

comments.text: I had some surface imperfections -- occasional bits of extrusion where the layers started -- on the 'inner' spool half's cylinder that I needed to sand down to get it to fit smoothly; if I were making another one, I'd be tempted to scale it to, say, 99% or 98% to give it a tiny extra bit of clearance so I could ignore that, but otherwise it works fine for me.
comments.author: sLpFhaWK

comments.text: I actually printed 2 of these and I had no issues with them going together or coming apart. So they definitely work as advertised. If your prints don't fit correctly its usually over extrusion, so dial back your extrusion multiplier and give it a go.
comments.author: srmalloy

comments.text: It looks to be a retraction issue, not an extrusion rate issue; what I'm seeing is occasional blebbing on the inside of the cylinder where the extruder finishes the perimeter, and it's not retracting fast enough to keep a small amount of extra melted filament from being left behind. It's not happening at all the layers, so I'm pretty sure I've got it close to right, just bump the retract speed a couple percent. Once I got the dozen or so blebs sanded down, everything fits properly.
comments.author: sLpFhaWK

I started with a simple sphere and sliced it in several pieces in ZBrush. Next, I created "Panel Loops" which gave each piece a nice thickness. With only four pieces, it certainly isn't much of a puzzle. But the technique can be extended to other shapes and more pieces.  
All four pieces are in one object to print. I spaced them apart so they can be separated easily once the printing is done. I like it when the printable thing looks interesting besides the finished object.  
When I was photographing it, I stuck an LED light inside to see what it would look like. With the room lights off, it reminds me of putting a candle inside a pumpkin. Again, it gave me some ideas about what I could do with this type of design.

I used ReplicatorG to prepare the file, a MakerBot Replicator2 with the Replicator2 slicing defaults and the following settings with white MakerBot PLA to do the printing: Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200
Shells = 1
Feedrate = 90
Travel Feed = 150
Temperature = 230 I used a raft with full support. It took almost 6 hours to print at 70 mm high. Removing the support structure wasn't bad at all. I tried using MakerWare V2.3.2.37 to print it, but the inside of the top piece didn't print that well. MakerWare uses minimal support structure which is okay for some things, but not for this design. I like the MakerWare interface much better than ReplicatorG but the slicer isn't as good. Anyone know if this might be change in the future?

author: jasonleeweihan

description.text:
Hi All

This is a ABS/TPU printed suction cup that can be done with a single extruder by pausing and switching filament. The suction cup can be used on the end of a robot arm for Picking and Placing stuff. This design is meant to be a general example/starting point. No hookups are provided for a particular vacuum source. Add what you need or your own setup.

Things that worked well:

  1. Bellows walls are 0.4mm thick, any more and the cup is too ridged.
  2. No more than 45 degree angle.
  3. 6mm long on the "Increasing Diameter" half of the bellow is about as long as you want, and even at that length the upper part start to bend inward a bit due to plastic contracting. The decreasing diameter section of the bellow prints just fine.
  4. Sticking with .1mm layer height on the bellows worked out better than 0.2
  5. Upped the TPU temp to 230 for better layer adhesion.
  6. You want more (AKA thicker) material on the inside of the cup lip. This provides a spring force to pull the lip back over center and prevent it from folding upward. (See video)
  7. I sliced it twice, once for ABS and once or TPU, then manually spliced the Gcode together. Beware using different layer heights. If you transition from 0.2 to 0.1 you might miss 0.1mm of the transition layer, if your not careful. ALSO NOTE: add extra extrusion (about 14mm for my bownden tube length of 20") to make sure enough pressure is immediately applied to the TPU to ensure a nice thick, well extruded first TPU layer. Else you will get a heavily underextruded first layer, and the cup will leak, and maybe break at that layer.
  8. Fan/Enclosure usage didn't seem to matter much at all to the TPU. (Enclosure good for ABS obviously)

I have found the TPU to be extremely tough, and always goes back to the printed shape. This same accordion design could be used a vibration isolation device.

ABS to TPU layer bonding has been good.

A test cup has been in the dishwasher for 3 weeks with no ill effects.

I had issues printing smaller diameter cups. I believe that was due to heat buildup and printing multiple cups at once should solve that issue.

Please post your makes/modifications to this design.

https://youtu.be/q1MWsZH-f90

title: Logitech C270 Webcam Mount for Original Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
The camera mount was inspired by the Logitech C270 mount by kareem613 and the Prusa i3 MK2 Sport Camera Holder created by mikolaszuza. Their inspirations, along with the fantastic customizer Nuts and Bolts by mike_mattala are linked in the Remix section.

The mount slips over the Y-carriage frame support on front right side of the MK2. The C270 camera mount is attached to the camera using it's own hinge pin. The dual diameter bolt fits through the sliding mount. The collar slides down from the top, leaving the M5 diameter threads available for the camera mount and nuts. I use two nuts to act as a locking nut arrangement.

Note: To remove the original weighted Logitech mount from the camera, use a thin knife to remove the covers over the ends of the hinge pin. You should then be able to use a screwdriver to remove the pin. You may need to push the pin out with a thin screwdriver or similar tool. The printed camera mount will be loose on the hinge. I used a small (M3?) metal washer at one end of the hinge pin, and a very small rubber washer at the other end of the hinge pin as shown in the photos above.

The C270 field of view is quite narrow. The camera can not see the whole bed. I plan to experiment with different lens/lens covers to try for a wider field of view.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

You may need supports on certain pieces depending on what orientation you print. The bolt, for example, will print much faster laying on the bed, but will need supports. I also used supports for the C270 camera mount.

Note that the sliding bracket needs to be able to handle the heat from the MK42 heated bed. I used Raptor PLA from MakerGeeks which I anneal in an oven after printing. It has held up well. ABS, PETG, or other high-temp PLAs such as the HTPLA from Proto-Pasta will work as well.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/wGiRUrG8S-A" ></iframe>

description.text:
I want my kids (who are just learning numbers) to have something to help make math fun, and easy to grasp. Keeping it simple I also integrated a few design elements for compact and neat storage. Updated!
Version 2:
  • Redesigned the pieces
  • Storage compartment bigger
  • Better hinges
  • STL to "print in-place" for hinges
  • Clasp to hold it together
  • Title "Intro to MATH" on the left side
  • Cleaned the tolerances so less plastic removal after print (if any)
    • EDIT: Zip file contains the individual pieces 1 through 9. Included a Pieces Set # 1 - Perfect starting quantity, ready for printing. Enjoy!

comments.text:
Very nice design - thanks for posting it here. Looks printable as well - will try this soon. One problem though - the "triangle" part with the bit's is too large to fir on the most of the printers bed (mine's 200 x 200 mm) so you need to either scali it down to about 90% or rotate it 55 degrees in Z axis to just about fit it diagonally. If you'll "fold" at least 3 top pieces to he left (se they'll be next to peices 4 - 6) it will fir much better smaller printer beds without need of scaling or rotating. Alternativelly- if you supply the bits individually it will not only fit but also allow for printing of multiply "values" as needed as well as possibility of using different colours (like red / greed for odd / even numbers and so on).
Also - looking on the number bits - they would need to be also flipped upside down to be printed properly (rotate around X or Y axis) but that could be indeed done in printing / slicing application so no need to adjust it in the project - just mention it in the instructions.

title: Gear Ornament for Christmas String Lights

description.text:
Modified Gear Ornament, altered to make it easy to insert string light bulbs to make the lighting more interesting.

Once built, if there is a web in the square, carefully use a knife to make diagonal cuts inside the square, from corner to opposite corner. Most tree lights should be able to gently push in to light up the ornament from the inside.

Printer:

MendelMax 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

None

Notes:

Vase mode, with 2 bottom layers. I used 3DXTech's clear ABS. I used a 0.6mm nozzle, slicer set to make a 0.72mm wide bead width. 0.5mm layer height might be worth trying too. 0.4mm gives good results too. For 0.4mm nozzles, try 0.3mm layers.

I took the Gear Ornament and added a square hole in the bottom to contain any fracture spreading. I also tapered the base more so it looked better for this task. I used TinkerCAD because it was quick to learn.

title: Prop safety/crash cage for Martian 95mm Brushed FPV Quad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Update 07.01.2017:
Added new versions (splitted and lighter).

For those who would like to fly this great micro quad by Chris Wilson inside your house.

Without saftey cage you need to be a real good pilot or fly slow or have a big room ... however, those props leave ugly marks on the furniture and walls, so you should protect them ;-)

This is fitted for use with max. 65mm Props. The motor mount holes are slightly smaller then my 8.5mm Motor housing to ensure tight fitting. I reamed of some material with a lexan reamer to make it fit perfectly and I advise you to do this to. Otherwise play with the model scale in your slicer depending on your filament. I printed this with PETG and this thing is damn strong and won't brake easily.

It weights about 8g printed. You may loose some more weight by adding some holes into the cage with a drill, but I didn't bother 2-3g, since the quad still flys great with this extra weight and inside the house it's not a real issue.

Important note!
The whole distance is not equal for all motor mounts. Therefore be sure to align the cage correctly before installing it.

Hope you like it.

comments.text: I made one of these. Thank you for making this and uploading it. My mom actually sent me the link to this thing here on thingiverse yesterday which was awesome that she was able to find one and know to get it off thingiverse. Anyways it worked except I had to edit the file slightly to make the top a little bit thicker. As water would leak through the cap like a coffee filter. My printer might just be suffering from a little under extrusion and instead of calibrating the e-steps it was easier to just edit the file. It works like a charm now.

Made a mobius strip as a part of the CAD subreddit's weekly challenge using Fusion 360.

This is a fairly simple printed chassis, requiring a minimal number of non-printed parts. It could be used for various robotics or rc uses.

Print list:
1X CrossBrace
2X CrossSupport
2X Pinion
2X Gearbox
4X Wheel

Non-printed parts:
2X RS-550 motors, or motors with same shaft/ mounting setup
8X bushing, 1/4" ID, 3/8" OD
4X 1/4" rod, cut roughly 1.5" each
11X M4x10mm bolts
4X M3x5 bolts
4X rubber wristbands

For instruction on how to build this chassis, look at the Instructable going over its assembly:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Simple-3D-Printed-Chassis/

I threaded the holes that the bolts mount into with an M4 tap, they seem to be holding up well.

It has been very durable and fun to use, but due to the single stage gearbox, is very high speed.

Message me if you have any questions about this project,
Enjoy!
